questions.question_en: Why are clouds white but rain clouds dark?
explanations_en: Wrong. Rain clouds aren't dirty - they're made of the same water droplets as white clouds. The darkness comes from their thickness, not contamination.

Correct! All clouds scatter sunlight, making them white. But rain clouds are much thicker and denser. As light passes through, most gets absorbed before reaching the bottom. Less light escapes, making them appear dark gray. The darker the cloud, the more water it holds, so rain is more likely!
Wrong. All clouds are made of water droplets or ice crystals. Rain clouds appear dark because they're thicker and denser, not because they're made of different materials.
Wrong. While rain clouds can cast shadows on the ground, their dark appearance is due to their thickness absorbing light as it passes through, not from shadows they create.
explanations_zh: 不对。雨云并不脏——它们和白云一样由水滴构成。其暗色源于厚度而非污染。
没错！所有云都会散射阳光，因此呈现白色。但雨云更为厚重密集。当光线穿透时，大部分在到达云底前就被吸收了。较少的光线能逸出，使得云看起来呈深灰色。云层越暗，含水量越高，下雨的可能性就越大！
不对。所有的云都是由水滴或冰晶构成的。雨云看起来颜色深是因为它们更厚更密，而不是因为构成物质不同。
错误。虽然雨云能在地面上投下阴影，但它们之所以看起来黑暗，是因为云层较厚，光线穿过时被吸收，而非由它们产生的阴影所致。

questions.question_en: Why does thunder come after lightning?
explanations_en: Wrong. Lightning itself doesn't travel - it's a discharge. The difference is that we see the light instantly because light travels much faster than the sound (thunder) travels to reach us.

Correct! Lightning and thunder happen at the same instant. But light travels at 300,000 km/s while sound only travels at 0.3 km/s - about a million times slower! So you see the flash almost instantly, but the sound takes time to reach you. Count the seconds between flash and thunder, divide by 3 to get distance in kilometers!
Wrong. Thunder is created instantly when lightning heats the air. The delay is because sound travels much slower than light, not because thunder takes time to form.
Wrong. Our eyes and ears process signals at similar speeds. The delay between seeing lightning and hearing thunder is due to light traveling vastly faster than sound.
explanations_zh: 不对。闪电本身并不移动——它是一种放电现象。区别在于我们瞬间看到光，因为光传播的速度远快于声音（雷声）传到我们这里所需的时间。
没错！闪电和雷声是同时发生的。但光速为每秒30万公里，而声音仅以每秒0.3公里的速度传播——大约慢了一百万倍！因此你几乎瞬间就能看到闪光，但声音需要时间才能传到你的耳朵。数一数闪电和雷声之间的秒数，再除以3，就能得出距离的公里数！
不对。雷声是闪电瞬间加热空气时立即产生的。延迟是因为声音传播速度远慢于光速，而不是因为雷声需要时间形成。
不对。我们的眼睛和耳朵处理信号的速度相近。看到闪电后听到雷声的延迟是因为光传播速度远快于声音。

explanations_en: Wrong. The sky is blue everywhere, even far from oceans. Actually, the ocean appears blue partly because it reflects the blue sky, not the other way around!

Correct! Sunlight is white, containing all colors. When it hits Earth's atmosphere, tiny air molecules scatter it. Blue light has shorter waves that scatter more easily than other colors. So blue light bounces everywhere in the sky while other colors pass through more directly, making the sky appear blue.
Wrong. The Sun emits white light containing all colors of the spectrum. The sky appears blue because Earth's atmosphere scatters blue light more than other colors.
Wrong. Our eyes can see all colors equally well. The sky looks blue because atmospheric molecules scatter blue wavelengths of sunlight more than other colors.
explanations_zh: 不对。天空在任何地方都是蓝色的，即使远离海洋也是如此。实际上，海洋呈现蓝色部分是因为它反射了蓝天，而不是相反！
没错！阳光是白色的，包含了所有颜色。当它照射到地球大气层时，微小的空气分子会将其散射。蓝光波长较短，比其他颜色更容易散射。因此，蓝光在天空中四处散射，而其他颜色则更直接地穿透，使得天空呈现蓝色。
不对。太阳发出的是包含光谱中所有颜色的白光。天空之所以呈现蓝色，是因为地球大气层对蓝光的散射作用比其他颜色更强。
错误。我们的眼睛对所有颜色的感知能力是相同的。天空呈现蓝色是因为大气中的分子对阳光中蓝色波长的散射作用比其他颜色更强。

choices_en: Air moves from high to low pressure
Trees wave and push the air
choices_zh: 空气从高压向低压流动
explanations_en: Wrong. Earth's rotation does affect wind direction (Coriolis effect), but it doesn't create wind. Wind is created by air pressure differences caused by uneven heating of Earth's surface.

Correct! Wind happens because air moves from high-pressure areas to low-pressure areas. The sun heats Earth's surface unevenly - some areas get warmer, creating low pressure as warm air rises. Cooler air (high pressure) rushes in to fill the space, creating wind. The greater the pressure difference, the stronger the wind!
Wrong. Trees don't create wind - they move because of wind! Wind is air in motion caused by pressure differences in the atmosphere.
Wrong. Temperature changes air density and pressure, but doesn't make it vibrate to create wind. Wind forms when air moves from high-pressure to low-pressure areas.
explanations_zh: 错误。地球自转确实会影响风向（科里奥利效应），但并非产生风的原因。风是由地球表面受热不均引起的气压差异所产生的。
正确！风是由于空气从高压区向低压区流动而产生的。太阳不均匀地加热地球表面——某些区域变得更热，形成低压，因为暖空气上升。较冷的空气（高压）迅速涌入填补空间，从而形成风。气压差越大，风力就越强！
不对。树木不会产生风——它们是因为风而动的！风是大气中因压力差而产生的空气流动。
错误。温度变化会影响空气密度和压力，但不会使其振动产生风。风是在空气从高压区向低压区流动时形成的。

questions.question_en: Why is it colder at higher altitudes?
choices_en: Air is thinner and holds less heat
Air expands and cools as it rises
explanations_en: Wrong. Higher altitudes actually receive more direct sunlight with less atmospheric filtering. But the air can't hold that heat effectively due to lower pressure.
Wrong. While air is thinner at altitude, this isn't the main reason. The key is that rising air expands due to lower pressure, and expansion causes cooling through a process called adiabatic cooling.

Correct! As air rises, atmospheric pressure decreases. Lower pressure allows air to expand, and when gases expand, they cool down - this is adiabatic cooling. Temperature drops about 6.5°C per kilometer of altitude. So even though you're closer to the sun on a mountain, the air is much colder!
Wrong. Mountains don't block warm air in a way that explains altitude temperature. The cooling happens because rising air expands in lower pressure and loses heat through adiabatic cooling.
explanations_zh: 错误。实际上，海拔越高，接受的阳光越直接，大气过滤越少。但由于气压较低，空气无法有效保持热量。
错误。虽然高海拔地区空气稀薄，但这并非主要原因。关键在于上升的空气因压力降低而膨胀，而膨胀通过一种称为绝热冷却的过程导致温度下降。
正确！随着空气上升，大气压力降低。压力减小使得空气膨胀，而气体膨胀时会冷却——这就是绝热冷却。海拔每升高一公里，温度大约下降6.5°C。因此，尽管在山顶上离太阳更近，空气却要冷得多！
错误。山脉并不会以解释海拔温度的方式来阻挡暖空气。实际上，温度降低是因为上升的空气在较低压力下膨胀，并通过绝热冷却过程散失热量。

explanations_en: Wrong. Fog isn't a cloud that fell down. Fog forms at ground level when water vapor condenses, just like clouds form in the sky. Fog is essentially a cloud touching the ground!
Wrong. Fog is pure water droplets, not smoke. While pollution can make fog appear dirtier (smog), fog itself forms when water vapor condenses in cool air.

Correct! Fog forms when air cools to its dew point - the temperature where water vapor condenses into tiny droplets. This often happens at night when the ground cools, chilling the air above it. Millions of suspended water droplets scatter light, reducing visibility. Fog is basically a cloud at ground level!
Wrong. Fog is made of liquid water droplets, not ice crystals. Ice fog can form in extremely cold conditions (below -30°C), but regular fog is liquid water suspended in air.
explanations_zh: 不对。雾并非从天而降的云。雾是在地面形成的水汽凝结现象，正如云在天空中形成一样。雾实质上就是接触地面的云！
错误。雾是纯净的水滴，而非烟雾。虽然污染可能使雾看起来更脏（形成烟雾），但雾本身是在冷空气中水蒸气凝结时形成的。
正确！雾的形成是当空气冷却至其露点——水蒸气凝结成微小水滴的温度。这通常发生在夜间，当地面冷却时，会使上方的空气变冷。数以百万计的悬浮水滴散射光线，从而降低能见度。雾实质上就是地面上的云！
错误。雾是由液态水滴组成的，而非冰晶。在极寒条件下（低于零下30摄氏度）可能形成冰雾，但常规雾是悬浮在空气中的液态水。

questions.question_en: Why do clouds float in the sky?
explanations_en: Wrong. Wind moves clouds sideways but doesn't hold them up. Clouds float because tiny water droplets fall so slowly that rising air currents keep them suspended.

Wrong. Water is actually denser than air! Cloud droplets are extremely tiny (about 0.01mm) and fall very slowly - only about 1 cm per second. Rising air moves upward faster than droplets fall, keeping clouds aloft.

Correct! Cloud droplets are tiny and fall very slowly. But warm air constantly rises from Earth's surface through convection. This upward air movement (updraft) is faster than the droplets' fall speed, keeping them suspended. When droplets grow heavy enough (combining into raindrops), they overcome the updraft and fall as rain!

Wrong. While clouds contain some electrical charge (creating lightning), static electricity doesn't hold clouds up. Clouds float because rising air currents support tiny, slowly-falling water droplets.
explanations_zh: 不对。风使云横向移动，但并不支撑它们。云能飘浮是因为微小的水滴下落速度极慢，上升的气流使它们保持悬浮状态。
不对。实际上，水的密度比空气大！云滴极其微小（约0.01毫米），下落速度非常缓慢——每秒仅约1厘米。上升气流的上升速度超过了云滴的下落速度，从而使云悬浮在空中。
没错！云滴微小且下落缓慢。但暖空气通过对流不断从地表上升。这股上升气流的速度超过了云滴的下落速度，使它们悬浮在空中。当云滴增长到足够重（合并成雨滴）时，它们便能克服上升气流，以雨的形式落下！
错误。虽然云层带有一定的电荷（从而产生闪电），但静电并不能支撑云朵漂浮。云之所以能飘浮，是因为上升的气流托住了那些微小且缓慢下落的水滴。

explanations_en: Wrong. 'Too heavy' is imprecise. Rain happens when individual droplets grow large enough that gravity pulls them down faster than rising air can hold them up.

Correct! Cloud droplets are tiny (0.01mm) and stay suspended in air. Rain forms when millions of these droplets collide and merge, growing into drops about 2-5mm. At this size, gravity overcomes the rising air currents, and they fall as rain. Warm clouds use collision; cold clouds form ice crystals that melt while falling!
Wrong. Temperature changes can affect cloud formation, but rain occurs when droplets grow large enough to fall. In warm clouds, droplets merge; in cold clouds, ice crystals form and fall.
Wrong. Clouds don't 'absorb' water like a sponge. They're made of suspended droplets that merge and grow until they're heavy enough to overcome updrafts and fall as rain.
explanations_zh: 不对。“太重”这个说法不准确。实际上，雨滴是在单个水滴增长到足够大，以至于重力使其下落速度超过上升气流支撑能力时形成的。
正确！云滴极小（0.01毫米），能悬浮于空气中。当数百万云滴碰撞合并，形成约2-5毫米的水滴时便形成降雨。此时重力胜过上升气流，水滴便以雨的形式落下。暖云通过碰撞形成降雨；冷云则形成冰晶，下落过程中融化成雨！
错误。温度变化确实会影响云的形成，但降雨是在云滴增大到足以降落时发生的。在暖云中，云滴合并；在冷云中，冰晶形成并降落。
不对。云并不像海绵那样“吸收”水分。它们是由悬浮的水滴组成的，这些水滴会合并并增大，直到重量足以克服上升气流，从而以雨的形式落下。

questions.question_en: Why do we see our breath in cold weather?
explanations_en: Wrong. Cold doesn't make breath visible by itself. The visibility comes from water vapor in your warm breath condensing into tiny droplets when it meets cold air.

Correct! Your breath contains water vapor from your lungs. When you exhale into cold air, the warm moisture suddenly cools below its dew point and condenses into tiny water droplets, forming a visible mist - just like a miniature cloud! The colder the air, the more dramatic the effect.
Wrong. Oxygen doesn't freeze at winter temperatures (it freezes at -218°C!). The visible mist is water vapor condensing, not frozen gases.
Wrong. Your breath doesn't contain ice particles. The visible cloud forms when water vapor from your warm, moist breath condenses into tiny liquid droplets upon meeting cold air.
explanations_zh: 不对。寒冷本身并不会让呼吸可见。可见性来自于你温暖呼吸中的水蒸气在遇到冷空气时凝结成微小水滴。
没错！你呼出的气息中含有来自肺部的水蒸气。当你向冷空气中呼气时，温暖的湿气突然冷却至露点以下，凝结成微小的水滴，形成可见的雾气——就像一朵微缩的云！空气越冷，这种效果就越明显。
错误。氧气在冬季温度下不会冻结（它在-218°C才结冰！）。可见的雾气是水蒸气凝结而成，并非冻结的气体。
不对。你呼出的气息中并不含有冰粒。那可见的云雾状现象是因为你温暖湿润的呼出水蒸气遇到冷空气后凝结成了微小的液滴。

questions.question_en: Why does ice form on windows in winter?
explanations_en: Wrong. Window ice usually forms on the inside, not from outside rain. It's created when indoor water vapor contacts the freezing cold window surface.

Correct! Indoor air contains water vapor from breathing, cooking, and other activities. When this warm, moist air touches a very cold window (below 0°C), the vapor deposits directly as ice crystals, skipping the liquid phase - a process called deposition. The beautiful frost patterns form because ice grows along scratches and imperfections in the glass!
Wrong. Cold air can hold very little moisture. The ice on windows comes from indoor water vapor that freezes when it contacts the cold glass surface.
Wrong. Glass doesn't attract ice particles. Ice forms when water vapor in warm indoor air deposits directly onto the cold window surface, creating frost crystals.
explanations_zh: 不对。窗冰通常是在室内形成的，而不是来自外面的雨水。它是当室内的水蒸气接触到冰冷的窗户表面时产生的。
正确！室内空气中含有呼吸、烹饪等活动产生的水蒸气。当这些温暖潮湿的空气接触到极冷的窗户（低于0°C）时，水蒸气会直接凝结成冰晶，跳过液态阶段——这一过程称为凝华。美丽的霜花图案之所以形成，是因为冰晶会沿着玻璃上的划痕和瑕疵生长！
不对。冷空气几乎无法容纳水分。窗户上的冰霜来自室内水蒸气，当它接触到冰冷的玻璃表面时便会结冰。
不对。玻璃并不会吸引冰粒。当室内温暖空气中的水蒸气直接沉积在冰冷的窗户表面时，就会形成冰晶，也就是霜。

choices_en: Humid air is heavier to breathe
Sweat can't evaporate to cool us
explanations_en: Wrong. While humid air is slightly denser, this doesn't affect breathing. Discomfort comes from your body's inability to cool itself through sweat evaporation.

Correct! Your body cools itself by sweating - as sweat evaporates from your skin, it takes heat with it. But evaporation requires dry air. In high humidity, air is already saturated with water vapor, so sweat can't evaporate. It just sits on your skin, leaving you hot, sticky, and unable to cool down effectively!
Wrong. Water vapor doesn't block oxygen - air contains both. High humidity feels uncomfortable because saturated air prevents sweat from evaporating, blocking your body's cooling system.
Wrong. Humidity doesn't change air temperature. It feels hotter because humid air prevents sweat evaporation, stopping your body's natural cooling mechanism.
explanations_zh: 错误。虽然潮湿空气密度稍大，但这并不影响呼吸。不适感源于身体无法通过汗液蒸发来有效降温。
没错！你的身体通过出汗来降温——汗水从皮肤蒸发时带走热量。但蒸发需要干燥的空气。在高湿度环境下，空气已饱含水分，汗水无法蒸发，只会停留在皮肤表面，让你感到闷热黏腻，无法有效降温！
错误。水蒸气不会阻碍氧气——空气中两者并存。高湿度让人感到不适是因为饱和的空气阻止了汗液蒸发，阻碍了身体的散热系统。
不对。湿度并不会改变空气温度。感觉更热是因为潮湿的空气阻碍了汗液蒸发，从而阻止了身体的自然冷却机制。

explanations_en: Wrong. Earth's rotation (Coriolis effect) affects large systems like hurricanes but is too weak to create tornadoes. Tornado spin comes from wind shear - winds at different heights moving in different directions.

Correct! Tornadoes form when winds at different heights blow in different directions or speeds (wind shear). This creates a horizontal spinning effect. When a powerful thunderstorm updraft tilts this rotation vertical and tightens it, a tornado forms. As the spinning column narrows (conservation of angular momentum), it spins faster - like a figure skater pulling in their arms!
Wrong. While rising hot air is part of thunderstorms, it doesn't create the spin. Tornado rotation comes from wind shear being tilted vertical by updrafts, then tightening into a vortex.

Wrong. Lightning is an electrical discharge and doesn't create spinning air. Tornado rotation comes from wind shear - different wind speeds at different heights creating rotation that gets tilted and tightened by updrafts.
explanations_zh: 错误。地球自转（科里奥利效应）会影响飓风等大型系统，但力量太弱无法形成龙卷风。龙卷风的旋转来源于风切变——即不同高度的风以不同方向运动。
正确！龙卷风的形成是由于不同高度的风向或风速不同（风切变），这会产生水平旋转效应。当强烈的雷暴上升气流将这种旋转转为垂直并收紧时，龙卷风就形成了。随着旋转柱变窄（角动量守恒），它旋转得更快——就像花样滑冰运动员收紧手臂一样！
错误。虽然上升的热空气是雷暴的一部分，但它并不产生旋转。龙卷风的旋转来自于风切变被上升气流倾斜至垂直方向，随后收紧形成涡旋。
不对。闪电是一种电放电现象，不会产生旋转的空气。龙卷风的旋转来源于风切变——即不同高度风速的差异形成的旋转，随后被上升气流倾斜并收紧。

questions.question_en: Why does dew form on grass in the morning?
explanations_en: Wrong. While plants do transpire water, dew comes from water vapor in the air, not from plants. It forms when air cools enough for its moisture to condense on cool surfaces.

Correct! At night, grass and ground cool by radiating heat to space. Air touching these cool surfaces drops below its dew point - the temperature where water vapor condenses. Moisture in the air then condenses into droplets on the cool grass. Clear, calm nights create the most dew because heat radiates away efficiently without clouds or wind!
Wrong. Dew isn't fog settling - it's water vapor condensing directly onto cool surfaces. Fog is suspended droplets in air; dew forms on surfaces when they cool below the air's dew point.
Wrong. Dew doesn't come from underground - it forms from water vapor in the air. When surfaces cool overnight, air moisture condenses on them as tiny droplets.
explanations_zh: 不对。虽然植物确实会蒸腾水分，但露水来源于空气中的水蒸气，而非植物。当空气冷却到一定程度，其水分就会在冷表面上凝结形成露水。
正确！夜晚，草地和地面通过向太空辐射热量而冷却。接触这些冷却表面的空气温度降至露点以下——即水蒸气凝结的温度。随后，空气中的湿气在凉爽的草叶上凝结成水滴。晴朗无风的夜晚露水最多，因为此时热量能有效地散发，没有云层或风的干扰！
错误。露水不是雾沉降形成的，而是水蒸气直接在冷表面上凝结而成。雾是悬浮在空气中的水滴；当表面冷却至空气露点以下时，就会形成露水。
不对。露水并非来自地下——它是由空气中的水蒸气形成的。当地表在夜间冷却时，空气中的水分会在上面凝结成小水滴。

choices_en: Ice is thrown up and down in clouds
explanations_en: Wrong. Rain doesn't freeze while falling to make hail. Hailstones form inside thunderclouds where strong updrafts repeatedly lift ice particles through freezing zones, building up layers.

Correct! Hail forms in powerful thunderstorms with strong updrafts. Ice particles get lifted above the freezing level, collect supercooled water droplets, freeze, then fall. But updrafts throw them up again! This cycle repeats, building concentric ice layers like an onion. When hailstones grow too heavy for updrafts to lift (some reach baseball size!), they finally fall to the ground.
Wrong. Lightning doesn't freeze water - it's an electrical discharge. Hail forms when strong updrafts repeatedly cycle ice through freezing zones, building layers of ice.
Wrong. While thunderstorms have temperature contrasts, hail specifically forms when strong updrafts repeatedly lift ice particles through freezing levels, allowing layers to accumulate.
explanations_zh: 不对。雨在下落过程中并不会结冰形成冰雹。冰雹是在雷暴云内部形成的，强烈的上升气流反复将冰粒抬升到冻结区域，使其层层累积而成。
正确！冰雹形成于具有强烈上升气流的强大雷暴中。冰粒被抬升到冰点以上，捕获过冷水滴后冻结并下落，但上升气流再次将它们抛起！这一过程循环往复，形成如洋葱般的同心冰层。当冰雹增长到上升气流无法支撑其重量时（有些甚至能达到棒球大小！），它们最终坠落地面。
不对。闪电不会冻结水——它是一种放电现象。冰雹是在强上升气流反复将冰粒带入冻结区域，层层积累冰层时形成的。
错误。虽然雷暴中存在温度差异，但冰雹的形成特别依赖于强烈的上升气流反复将冰粒抬升至冻结层以上，使其层层累积而成。

questions.question_en: Why does wind feel colder than still air?
questions.question_zh: 风为何比静止空气更冷？
choices_en: Wind removes warm air near skin
explanations_en: Wrong. Wind doesn't have to be colder - even at the same temperature, wind feels colder than still air. The difference is that wind constantly removes the warm air layer near your skin.

Correct! Your body warms a thin layer of air next to your skin. In still air, this warm layer insulates you. But wind constantly blows this warm air away and replaces it with cooler air, forcing your body to work harder to stay warm. This 'wind chill' effect makes 10°C with wind feel much colder than 10°C without wind!
Wrong. Moving air doesn't have less heat than still air at the same temperature. Wind feels colder because it removes the warm insulating layer of air around your body faster than still air.
Wrong. Wind doesn't increase air pressure in a way that affects temperature sensation. Wind feels colder because it removes the warm air layer your body creates, increasing heat loss.
explanations_zh: 不对。风不一定更冷——即使在相同温度下，风也比静止空气感觉更冷。区别在于风会持续吹走皮肤附近的温暖空气层。
没错！你的身体会温暖皮肤表面的一薄层空气。在静止的空气中，这层温暖的空气能为你保温。但风会不断吹走这层暖空气，并用较冷的空气替代，迫使身体更努力地产热以维持体温。这种“风寒”效应使得有风时的10°C感觉比无风时冷得多！
错误。流动的空气并不比静止的空气在相同温度下热量少。风感觉更冷是因为它比静止空气更快地带走了身体周围的温暖保温空气层。
不对。风并不会以影响温度感知的方式增加气压。风之所以让人感觉更冷，是因为它吹走了身体周围形成的暖空气层，从而加快了热量流失。

questions.question_en: Why do snowflakes have six sides?
choices_zh: 水分子以六边形方式结合。
六是大自然的幸运数字。
explanations_en: Wrong. Air molecules don't have shapes that influence snowflakes. The structure comes from water itself.

Correct! Water molecules bond at 120-degree angles due to hydrogen bonding. When ice crystals form, this angle creates six-fold symmetry. Each snowflake branch grows differently based on temperature and humidity it encounters—that's why each is unique!
Wrong. Six isn't lucky—it's physics! Water's molecular bonding angle naturally creates hexagonal structures.
Wrong. Wind doesn't create the six-sided shape. The structure is determined by water's molecular bonding angles.
explanations_zh: 错误。空气分子并不具备影响雪花形状的结构，雪花的形态源于水本身。
正确！水分子因氢键作用以120度角结合。当冰晶形成时，这种角度产生了六重对称性。每片雪花的枝杈根据其所遇温度和湿度的不同而各异生长——这就是每片雪花都独一无二的原因！
错。六并非幸运数字——这是物理原理！水分子间的键角自然形成了六边形结构。
不对。风并不会形成六边形结构。这种结构是由水分子间的键合角度决定的。

questions.question_en: Why are sunsets more colorful than sunrises?
questions.question_zh: 为什么日落比日出色彩更丰富？
choices_zh: 夜晚空气中颗粒物更多
我们的眼睛在一夜之间适应了。
explanations_en: Correct! By evening, human activity has released more dust, pollution, and particles into the air. These scatter more light, creating vivid reds and oranges. Morning air is cleaner after particles settled overnight. Sunsets after storms can be spectacular!
Wrong. The Sun's temperature doesn't change. Color differences come from atmospheric particles, not solar temperature.
Wrong. Eye adaptation doesn't explain sunset colors. The atmosphere contains more particles in evening.
Wrong. The direction doesn't matter. Evening air everywhere has accumulated more particles from daily activity.
explanations_zh: 没错！到了傍晚，人类活动向空气中释放了更多的尘埃、污染物和颗粒物。这些物质散射更多光线，从而形成鲜艳的红色和橙色。而早晨的空气经过一夜的沉淀更为洁净。暴风雨后的日落景象尤为壮观！
不对。太阳的温度不会改变。颜色的差异来自大气中的粒子，而非太阳的温度。
错误。眼睛适应并不能解释日落色彩。傍晚时分大气中含有更多颗粒物。
不对。方向无关紧要。傍晚的空气中，各处都积聚了更多日常活动产生的颗粒物。
